questions.question_text: Worldwide users from an organization are experiencing intermittent access to a global cloud application. The cloud provider availability dashboard shows all resource availability has been 100% in the last two weeks. No network outages have been reported. Which of the following should the organization's administrator do BEFORE calling the cloud provider?

discussion.content: D is the correct answer

EXAMPLES OF ROLE-BASED ACCESS CONTROL
Through RBAC, you can control what end-users can do at both broad and granular levels. You can designate whether the user is an administrator, a specialist user, or an end-user, and align roles and access permissions with your employees’ positions in the organization. Permissions are allocated only with enough access as needed for employees to do their jobs.

questions.question_text: A cloud deployment engineer is modifying versions of the existing template image to instantiate new VMs. The engineer accomplishes this through the cloud self- service portal. After the version is changed and a new VM is successfully started, it does not have any connectivity, and all ping tests to other VMs fail. Which of the following would be the BEST approach to solve the problem?

choices.D: Assign new IPs to the newly created VMs by changing and running the deployment template; and check the connectivity on the cloud self-service portal afterward.
choices.A: Start the console session to the VM; check network static routes; test the ping to default gateway and next hop; and reconfigure the gateway IP.
choices.C: Delete the VM; check the IP assignment and planning; modify configuration in the deployment template; and instantiate the VM again using the new template.
choices.B: Delete the VM; create a new flavor; turn on network service; add the new image to the template manager; and reinstantiate the VM using this new image.

discussion.content: D is the answer

I don't see any template that can be redeployed on top of an existing VM. 

looking at VMware all I see is an option to update the template and then deploy a new VM.
https://www.nakivo.com/blog/vm-templates-a-to-z/

Going with C.
Right answer is C

comments.content: Was torn between C and D but I believe with templates you can apply them to current/running instances and they will update, so in that case I wouldn't see the need to delete and instantiate a VM... D it is!
there's no problem with the gateway IP, these copies use a template and are therefore assigned the same IP's as the original. they just need to be assigned a new ip

discussion.content: Correct answer would be A

The answer is B 
I agree with Kassa, your insider will have access to tokens being inside your organization that wont stop him. BUT if the drive is encrypted that stops EVERYONE

B is the correct answer - A does not address the question as written but enabling FDE with an encryption key that is not known/needed by the operations team ensures that cloning and trying to rebuild into a new machine with the encrypted disk copy can't be read.

questions.question_text: A cloud provider is evaluating an insider threat. A resource from the company operations team has access to the servers' virtual disks. This poses a risk that someone could copy and move the virtual server image and have access to the data. Which of the following solutions would help mitigate this problem?

A cloud administrator is analyzing usage trends for a website housed within an IaaS cloud platform. The administrator notices that traffic and visitors to the site quadrupled from the normal baseline during the holiday season. The environment has a load balancer that uses standardized VMs to host the applications. Given this scenario, which of the following would be the MOST efficient, provide no downtime, and address the temporary spike in traffic?

discussion.content: D- requirement "no down time"
I would say D, horizontal scaling would be the way to go.
the discussion focus on "no downtime", but the question said "The environment has a load balancer", both horizontal/vertical will not cause down time. so A for me, can address temporary traffic spike

comments.content: the word "standardized VMs" may indicate something, A again.

discussion.content: going with D. No downtime and easier deployment.

D, and the key word here is "The environment has a load balancer that uses standardized VMs to host the applications." it uses a load balancer, and if we increase resources, the load balancer is useless here. These are standardize VMs, so horizontal scaling is possible.
the answer is D

The correct answer is A; the solution should cause no downtime and be able to handle the spike. Horizontal scaling requires changes that results in downtime which vertical scaling doesnot. 
Vertical scaling can essentially resize your server with no change to your code. It is the ability to increase the capacity of existing hardware or software by adding resources. Vertical scaling is limited by the fact that you can only get as big as the size of the server.

Horizontal scaling affords the ability to scale wider to deal with traffic. It is the ability to connect multiple hardware or software entities, such as servers, so that they work as a single logical unit. This kind of scale cannot be implemented at a moment’s notice.
https://www.ibm.com/blogs/cloud-computing/2014/04/09/explain-vertical-horizontal-scaling-cloud/

comments.content: I think the answer would be horizontal scaling as the question hints there is load balancing in place for a reason. Many cloud providers state you cannot change a VM after it is initiated. It would need to be reconfigured completely AKA have downtime.
A does cause downtime. So Answer is D

https://www.missioncloud.com/blog/horizontal-vs-vertical-scaling-which-is-right-for-your-app#:~:text=With%20vertical%20scaling%20(a.k.a.%20%E2%80%9Cscaling,memory%20workload%20across%20multiple%20devices.
"Horizontal scaling is almost always more desirable than vertical scaling because you don’t get caught in a resource deficit. Instead of taking your server offline while you’re scaling up to a better one, horizontal scaling lets you keep your existing pool of computing resources online while adding more to what you already have. When your app is scaled horizontally, you have the benefit of elasticity."

discussion.content: D is the answer
this is wrong, scaling vertically typically comes with some downtime to add more nodes or replace the machine with an upgraded machine. The answer should be outward horizontal scaling

comments.content: this is true, nothing was said of cost efficiency so horizontal scaling is the most efficient option to prevent downtime

choices.B: Implement a downward vertical scaling solution.
choices.C: Implement an inward horizontal scaling solution.
choices.D: Implement an outward horizontal scaling solution.
choices.A: Implement an upward vertical scaling solution.
